conclusion: To determine whether the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph step by step.
The velocity-time graph provides information about the velocity of the particle at different times. The slope of the graph represents the acceleration of the particle.
Flat horizontal segments (zero slope) indicate constant velocity (no acceleration), and sloped segments (non-zero slope) indicate changing velocity (acceleration or deceleration).
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the graph is a horizontal line at v = 2 m/s.
Since the velocity is constant (no change) from t = 0 to t = 1 second, the particle is undergoing uniform linear motion (no acceleration).
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the graph is a straight line sloping downward from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s.
The slope is negative from t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, indicating the particle is decelerating (velocity is decreasing).
During the interval t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the particle is undergoing variable linear motion because its velocity is changing.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the graph is a straight line sloping downward from v = 0 m/s to v = -2 m/s.
The slope is negative from t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, indicating the particle is accelerating in the negative direction (velocity is becoming more negative).
During the interval t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the particle is undergoing variable linear motion because its velocity is changing.
In the first 1 second (t = 0 to t = 1), the particle's velocity is constant, so it does not undergo variable linear motion.
In the next 2 seconds (t = 1 to t = 3), the particle's velocity changes continuously, indicating variable linear motion.
Yes, the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, but only during the intervals t = 1 s to t = 3 s.
